His suggestion on how to deal with the thief was invaluable, but the police considered it................
explanation:
For something to be invaluable, it is extremely useful; indispensable.
Option A (useless) is the most nearly opposite in meaning.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
The outgoing president warned his successor to beware of ................who praise every action of government, good or bad.
explanation: The correct word to complete the sentence is"sycophants" (Option B). Sycophants are individuals who excessively flatter or praise someone, regardless of whether the actions being praised are good or bad. The outgoing president is warning his successor about such people—those who might praise every government action uncritically.

To give a bronze medal to the athlete who was deliberately intercepted on the track was cold comfort This means that the bronze medal was
explanation: The phrase"cold comfort"meansa small or inadequate consolation for a loss or unfair treatment. In this context, the athlete wasdeliberately intercepted(hindered unfairly), and giving them a bronze medal wasnot enough to make up for the injustice.

text:
From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
The woman stifled a cry of astonishment as she discovered the identity of the robber.
explanation: In this context, "stifled" means to hold back or suppress an expression, in this case, a cry of astonishment. The woman is controlling or restraining herself from crying out loud due to astonishment upon discovering the identity of the robber.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
Our teacher is leaving our school in July to ...............a new job
explanation:
The phrase "take up a new job" is commonly used to mean starting or accepting a new job or position.
To "take in" means to absorb or understand something, or to allow someone to stay in your home.
To "take to"  means to develop a liking for something or to begin doing something as a habit.
To "take on" means to accept a challenge or responsibility. While it can sometimes be used in the context of starting a job, "take up" is the more commonly used phrase for accepting a new job.

The old woman had no children and no real friends..........

Certain tasks may be unpleasant at first, but gradually one may get.............them

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
.................In their youth is a source of pleasurable reminiscence for elderly persons
explanation:
"To have travelledin their youth is a source of pleasurable reminiscence for elderly persons."
"To have travelled" is correct because it expresses that the action of travelling occurred in the past and this is now a source of fond memories for elderly persons.
"To be travelling"  refers to the continuous action of travelling. "To travel" refers to the act of travelling but does not express the fact that the action occurred in the past. "By travelling" suggests a means or method and not an action completed in the past.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The principal has gone to Freetown and will come back in ..............time.
explanation:
In the sentence "The principal has gone to Freetown and will come back in two weeks' time," the apostrophe should be used after "weeks" as "weeks' time." The use of the apostrophe in "weeks' time" indicates possession or ownership. This construction is a common and idiomatic way to express a duration of time in English. It's used to specify when something will happen or for how long.
The apostrophe is placed after "weeks" because it is a plural noun. When forming the possessive form of a plural noun that ends with an "s," we typically add only an apostrophe after the "s" (e.g., "the students' books," "two weeks' time").

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The school high jump champion has been................

options.A: off very much from most of the time
options.B: very much off-from most of the time
options.C: very most off-from most of the time
options.D: off-from the most of the very much

explanation:
The sentence "The school high jump champion has been off-from most of the time" suggests that the high jump champion has not been performing well or has been absent for most of the time. The phrase "off-from most of the time" implies a lack of consistency or regularity in the champion's performance or attendance.
Therefore, the option "very much off-from most of the time" is the most appropriate completion for the sentence. It means that the champion's performance or attendance has been consistently lacking or below expectations most of the time.
